query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 La sete natural che mai non sazia 2 se non con l’acqua onde la femminetta 3 samaritana domandò la grazia,
query.error: **English:** 1 The natural thirst that is never quenched 2 except by the water for which the little woman 3 of Samaria asked the favor,
query.result: 1 Se ðurst ðe næfre ne gesaðað 2 būton ðurh ðæt wæter ðe ðæt wifmann 3 Samaritaniscum bæd ðære gife,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 mi travagliava, e pungeami la fretta 5 per la ’mpacciata via dietro al mio duca, 6 e condoleami a la giusta vendetta.
query.error: **English:** 4 tormented me, and the haste pricked me 5 along the difficult path behind my guide, 6 and I grieved for the just vengeance.
query.result: 4 me ðurstes ða, and ða ðurst me dyde 5 ðurh ðone weg unrihte æfter minum latteowe, 6 and ic me geomrode ðære rihtwisan wracðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Ed ecco, sì come ne scrive Luca 8 che Cristo apparve a’ due ch’erano in via, 9 già surto fuor de la sepulcral buca,
query.error: **English:** 7 And behold, just as Luke writes to us 8 that Christ appeared to the two who were on the way, 9 already risen from the sepulchral cave,
query.result: 7 And eac, swa us Lucas awrat, 8 ðæt Crist ætywde ðam twam ðe wæron on wege, 9 of ðam byrgene arisan,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 ci apparve un’ombra, e dietro a noi venìa, 11 dal piè guardando la turba che giace; 12 né ci addemmo di lei, sì parlò pria,
query.error: **English:** 10 a shade appeared to us, and came behind us, 11 watching at our feet the crowd that lay there; 12 nor did we notice it, until it spoke first,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 dicendo: «O frati miei, Dio vi dea pace». 14 Noi ci volgemmo sùbiti, e Virgilio 15 rendéli ’l cenno ch’a ciò si conface.
query.error: **English:** 13 saying: "O my brothers, may God give you peace." 14 We turned suddenly, and Virgil 15 made the sign that is appropriate for this.
query.result: 13 and cwæð: "Eala, mine gebroðru, God eowic gife sibbe." 14 We wendon ða sona, and Vergilius 15 dyde ðone tacn ðe ðærto gebyrede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Poi cominciò: «Nel beato concilio 17 ti ponga in pace la verace corte 18 che me rilega ne l’etterno essilio».
query.error: **English:** 16 Then he began: "May the true court 17 place you in peace in the blessed council 18 that exiles me to eternal exile."
query.result: 16 ða ongan he secgan: "Ðæt soðe gemot 17 ðe sette on sibbe on ðam beorhtan ræde 18 ðe me wræceð on ðone ecan exilium."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 «Come!», diss’ elli, e parte andavam forte: 20 «se voi siete ombre che Dio sù non degni, 21 chi v’ha per la sua scala tanto scorte?».
query.error: **English:** 19 "Come!" he said, and we walked on quickly: 20 "If you are shades whom God does not deem worthy of heaven, 21 who has guided you so far up his ladder?"
query.result: 19 "Cumað!" cwæð he, and we forð gongende wæron: 20 "Gif ge synt ða gesceaftas ðe God ne demed wyrðe heofona, 21 hwa hæfð eow ðus feor on his stige gelædd?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 E ’l dottor mio: «Se tu riguardi a’ segni 23 che questi porta e che l’angel profila, 24 ben vedrai che coi buon convien ch’e’ regni.
query.error: **English:** 22 And my teacher: "If you look at the signs 23 that this man bears and that the angel outlined, 24 you will see clearly that he must reign with the good."
query.result: 22 And min lareow cwæð: "Gif ðu ða tacna gesihst 23 ðe ðeos man bær and ðe ðam engel awrat, 24 ðu gesyhst ðæt he sceal mid ðam godum rixian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Ma perché lei che dì e notte fila 26 non li avea tratta ancora la conocchia 27 che Cloto impone a ciascuno e compila,
query.error: **English:** 25 But because she who spins day and night 26 had not yet drawn for her the distaff 27 that Clotho allots and prepares for each person,
query.result: 25 Ac forðæm ðe heo ðe dæges and nihtes spint, 26 ne hæfde heo ða gyt ðone roccan atoh 27 ðe Clotho gesceapoð and gegearwoð ælcum men,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 l’anima sua, ch’è tua e mia serocchia, 29 venendo sù, non potea venir sola, 30 però ch’al nostro modo non adocchia.
query.error: **English:** 28 her soul, which is your sister and mine, 29 coming up, could not come alone, 30 because it does not see in our way.
query.result: 28 hire sawul, ðe is ðin sweostor and min, 29 upweard stigende, ne mihte cuman ana, 30 forðæm ðe heo on ure wisan ne gesihð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Ond’ io fui tratto fuor de l’ampia gola 32 d’inferno per mostrarli, e mosterrolli 33 oltre, quanto ’l potrà menar mia scola.
query.error: **English:** 31 And I was drawn out of the wide mouth 32 of hell to show it to him, and I will show him 33 beyond, as far as my teaching can lead him.
query.result: 31 And ic wæs ða fram ðære sidan utalæded 32 of helle ðurh ðæt ic him ða geswutelode, and ic him geswutelige 33 furðor, swa feor swa min lar gewendan mæg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Ma dimmi, se tu sai, perché tai crolli 35 diè dianzi ’l monte, e perché tutto ad una 36 parve gridare infino a’ suoi piè molli».
query.error: **English:** 34 But tell me, if you know, why the mountain shook 35 just now, and why it seemed to cry out 36 all the way down to its soft foot?
query.result: 34 Ac sege me, gif ðu wast, hwi ðeos munt saread 35 ær ðisum, and hwi he eall greowode 36 oð ðone grund, ðær he on fæstnunge stod?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Sì mi diè, dimandando, per la cruna 38 del mio disio, che pur con la speranza 39 si fece la mia sete men digiuna.
query.error: **English:** 37 So he gave me, in response to my question, through the opening 38 of my desire, which with hope alone 39 made my thirst less ravenous.
query.result: 37 Swa he me sealde, ða ic hine sylfne bæd, ðurh ða crune 38 mines willan, ðe ðurh ða wilnunge ana 39 worhte ða ðurst ðe me ðyrstede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Quei cominciò: «Cosa non è che sanza 41 ordine senta la religïone 42 de la montagna, o che sia fuor d’usanza.
query.error: **English:** 40 He began: "What is it that religion 41 of the mountain does not feel without 42 order, or that is out of custom?
query.result: 40 He ða ongan: "Hwæt nis ðæt ðe ðeos 41 muntes gesetnes ne onfindeð 42 butan gemet, oððe ðe sie unþeaw?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Libero è qui da ogne alterazione: 44 di quel che ’l ciel da sé in sé riceve 45 esser ci puote, e non d’altro, cagione.
query.error: **English:** 43 Here he is free from all alteration: 44 of that which heaven receives into itself from itself 45 there can be a cause, and of nothing else.
query.result: 43 Her is he freoh fram ælce forwandelunge: 44 ðæs ðe ðæt heofon of him sylfne on him sylfne onfehð 45 mæg beon gesceaft, and of nanum oðrum, orsorge.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

query.error: **English:** 46 Therefore neither rain, nor hail, nor snow, 47 nor dew, nor frost falls higher up 48 than the short stairway of three steps;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 secco vapor non surge più avante 53 ch’al sommo d’i tre gradi ch’io parlai, 54 dov’ ha ’l vicario di Pietro le piante.
query.error: **English:** 52 dry vapor does not rise any higher 53 than the top of the three steps of which I spoke, 54 where the vicar of Peter has his feet.
query.result: 52 druguð ne gæð furðor up 53 ðonne ðæs ðreo ðegna ðe ic ær nemde, 54 ðær se Petres nama hæfð geweald.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Trema forse più giù poco o assai; 56 ma per vento che ’n terra si nasconda, 57 non so come, qua sù non tremò mai.
query.error: **English:** 55 Perhaps it trembles a little or a lot further down; 56 but because of a wind that hides itself in the earth, 57 I do not know how, up here it never trembled.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Tremaci quando alcuna anima monda 59 sentesi, sì che surga o che si mova 60 per salir sù; e tal grido seconda.
query.error: **English:** 58 It trembles when a pure soul 59 feels itself, so that it may rise or move 60 to ascend; and such a cry follows it.
query.result: 58 Hyt bið ðonne halige gast 59 onfindeð ðæt he mot upahafen weorðan 60 and to heofonum gestigan; and swylc hream byð æfter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 De la mondizia sol voler fa prova, 62 che, tutto libero a mutar convento, 63 l’alma sorprende, e di voler le giova.
query.error: **English:** 61 Of the refuse alone it wishes to make trial, 62 which, wholly free to change its dwelling, 63 surprises the soul and rejoices in its desire.
query.result: 61 Of ðære unnyttan ðingum ðæt an ðæt hit willeð fandian, 62 ðæt, eall freoh to awendan mynster, 63 ða sawle oferclyppeð and ðæs willan ðæs gefeah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Prima vuol ben, ma non lascia il talento 65 che divina giustizia, contra voglia, 66 come fu al peccar, pone al tormento.
query.error: **English:** 64 At first it wills the good, but does not let 65 that divine justice, against its will, 66 as it was in sinning, put it to torment.
query.result: 64 Ærest willeð wel, ac ne læteð ðæt talente 65 ðe godcunde rihtwisnes, ongean willan, 66 swa swa hit wæs on synnum, settan on tintregum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 E io, che son giaciuto a questa doglia 68 cinquecent’ anni e più, pur mo sentii 69 libera volontà di miglior soglia:
query.error: **English:** 67 And I, who have lain in this pain 68 for five hundred years and more, only just now felt 69 the free will to reach a better threshold:
query.result: 67 And ic, ðe ðis geswinc ðrowode 68 fif hund wintra and ma, nu ic ða freolice 69 willan hæbbe ðæs beteran wuldorgewinnes:

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 però sentisti il tremoto e li pii 71 spiriti per lo monte render lode 72 a quel Segnor, che tosto sù li ’nvii».

query.result: 70 ðurh ðæt ðu ðone eorðstyrunge and ða arfæstan 71 gastas ðurh ðone munt godes herigean 72 ðone ðe hi sona onsended to ðam hehstan wuldre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Così ne disse; e però ch’el si gode 74 tanto del ber quant’ è grande la sete, 75 non saprei dir quant’ el mi fece prode.
query.error: **English:** 73 Thus he spoke to me; and because he enjoys 74 the good as much as his thirst is great, 75 I cannot tell how much he benefited me.
query.result: 73 Þus he sæde; and forðæm he hine glædðe 74 swa mycel ðæs gōdan swa his þurst wæs, 75 ne mæg ic secgan hu mycel he mē fremde.

query.prompt:

query.result: 79 Nu ðu ðe wære, ðæt ðu me secge, 80 and hwi ðu her on ðisse worulde 81 swa fela wintra wuniende wære».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Tanto fu dolce mio vocale spirto, 89 che, tolosano, a sé mi trasse Roma, 90 dove mertai le tempie ornar di mirto.
query.error: **English:** 88 So sweet was my voiceful spirit, 89 that, a Tolosan, Rome drew me to herself, 90 where I deserved to have my temples crowned with myrtle.
query.result: 88 Swa swete wæs min sanges gast, 89 ðæt Tolosan me to him teoh, 90 ðær ic wurde weorð myrðe to habbanne.

91 Stazio la gente ancor di là mi noma: 92 cantai di Tebe, e poi del grande Achille; 93 ma caddi in via con la seconda soma.

97 de l’Eneïda dico, la qual mamma 98 fummi, e fummi nutrice, poetando: 99 sanz’ essa non fermai peso di dramma.

query.result: 97 Be ðam Æneide ic secge, ðe me wæs modor 98 and wæs me fostormodor, ða ic ða leoð worhte: 99 buton hire ne meahte ic gewegan wæge draf.

106 ché riso e pianto son tanto seguaci 107 a la passion di che ciascun si spicca, 108 che men seguon voler ne’ più veraci.

118 dal mio maestro, e «Non aver paura», 119 mi dice, «di parlar; ma parla e digli 120 quel ch’e’ dimanda con cotanta cura».

query.result: 118 fram minum lareowe, and he cwæð to me, "Ne beo ðu afyrht 119 ðæt ðu sprecan mæge; ac sprec and sege him 120 ðæt he ðe mid swilcre gymene frineð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Ond’ io: «Forse che tu ti maravigli, 122 antico spirto, del rider ch’io fei; 123 ma più d’ammirazion vo’ che ti pigli.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Questi che guida in alto li occhi miei, 125 è quel Virgilio dal qual tu togliesti 126 forte a cantar de li uomini e d’i dèi.
query.error: **English:** 124 He who guides my eyes on high, 125 is that Virgil from whom you took 126 the power to sing of men and of gods.
query.result: 124 Se ðe lædeð upp mine eagan, 125 is se Vergilius of ðam ðu nome 126 strangne sang be mannum and be godum.

127 Se cagion altra al mio rider credesti, 128 lasciala per non vera, ed esser credi 129 quelle parole che di lui dicesti».

query.result: 127 Gif ðu ænig oðer ðing wendes ðæt min guma logon, 128 forlæt ðæt for unsoð, and gelyf ðæt 129 ða word ðe ðu be him spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Già s’inchinava ad abbracciar li piedi 131 al mio dottor, ma el li disse: «Frate, 132 non far, ché tu se’ ombra e ombra vedi».

query.result: 130 Þa he ongann hnigan to his fotum, 131 ac he him wiðcwæð: "Broðor min, ne do swa, 132 forðam ðe ðu eart sceadu and sceadu gesihst."

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

136 trattando l’ombre come cosa salda».
